conclusion: Shadows are created when an object blocks light from a source, and the position and size of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface onto which the shadow is cast.
In the first image, we see three shadows labeled A, B, and C cast by three objects: a birdcage, a cup, and a drumstick.
The light source is positioned to the left of these objects, causing the shadows to extend to the right.

premise: The light source moves to the right.
conclusion: The angle at which the light hits the objects changes, affecting both the position and size of the shadows.

premise: The light source moves to the right.
conclusion: As the light source moves to the right, the shadows will shift to the left.
The distance to each object may change slightly, but the primary effect is the change in angle.

premise: The light source moves closer to the objects.
conclusion: The shadows will become larger and more distorted.

premise: The light source moves further away from the objects.
conclusion: The shadows will become smaller and sharper.
In the second image, we observe the shadows after the light source has moved to the right.
Shadow A (birdcage) has shifted to the left and appears slightly smaller.
Shadow B (cup) has also shifted to the left and appears more elongated.
Shadow C (drumstick) has shifted to the left and appears slightly larger and more distorted.

premise: When the light source moves to the right, the shadows A, B, and C shift to the left.
conclusion: Shadow A becomes slightly smaller, shadow B becomes more elongated, and shadow C becomes larger and more distorted.
